llm_processed_output.source_summary: The provided text discusses the border dispute between Algeria and Morocco in 1963-1964. Morocco laid claim to a part of the Sahara Desert, which was then within French Algeria, after becoming independent in 1956. In 1963, following Algeria's independence, Morocco invaded the disputed territory. The Organization of African Unity (OAU) was newly formed at the time. Ethiopia and Mali, acting on behalf of the OAU's Provisional Secretariat, facilitated a meeting between the disputants in October 1963. This resulted in a cease-fire agreement, the establishment of a demilitarized zone determined by army officers from the four states (Algeria, Morocco, Ethiopia, and Mali), and supervision of the cease-fire and the zone by a Cease-Fire Commission composed of Ethiopian and Malian officers. The OAU was entrusted with finding a settlement to the dispute.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: The article 'Chou En-lai on Safari,' published in The China Quarterly in June 1964, discusses Chou En-lai's diplomatic tour of Africa and the Mediterranean. The tour, characterized as Peking's greatest diplomatic effort outside the Communist world, occurred after China's split from Russia and amidst strained relations with the US and India. It is presented as a turning point in Peking's foreign policy, with potential impact on international relations. Chou En-lai's original plan to visit African countries that recognized China was modified due to disturbances in East Africa in mid-January. Ultimately, he visited ten countries, eight of which had already established diplomatic recognition with China: the United Arab Republic (05/1956), Algeria (12/1958), Morocco (November 1958), Ghana (July 1960), Mali (October 1960), Guinea (October 1959), Sudan (February 1959), and Somalia (December 1960). A special visit to Tunisia resulted in the establishment of diplomatic relations. The revolution in Zanzibar (December 1963), and mutinies in Tanganyika (December 1961), Uganda (October 1962) and Kenya (December 1963) led to those countries being removed from Chou's itinerary, although he visited Ethiopia. He was accompanied by Marshal Ch'en Yi, the Foreign Minister, and a large entourage.

extracted_key_facts: The Organization of African Unity (OAU) was founded on May 25, 1963, in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

The OAU faced setbacks due to divisiveness among its members, including the existence of the radical Casablanca group and the conservative Monrovia group.
The African Union (AU) was established following the Sirte Declaration in September 1999 and the adoption of its constitutive act at the 35th OAU Summit in July 2000 in Lome, Togo.

The AU's objectives include greater unity, solidarity, sovereignty, territorial integrity, political and socioeconomic integration, promotion of African common positions, international cooperation, peace, security, stability, democratic principles, human rights, and sustainable development.
Nigeria played an important role in creating the Monrovia group, which unified the divisiveness between the Casablanca group and the Brazzaville group.

Key aspects include the initial uncertainty in defining the colony's territory, the role of cartography as a tool for control and appropriation, the resistance of the Algerian terrain and population to mapping, the negotiation of frontiers with neighboring entities, and the incorporation of the Sahara into the Algerian territory. The review highlights the continuous redrawing of frontiers, the transgressions by local populations, and the colonial discourse that accompanied these processes. Specific instances mentioned include tensions between military and civil authorities, the reliance on historical precedents (like Roman territorial organization), and the eventual attachment of Touat to Algeria in 1891, accompanied by a colonial discourse denying indigenous ownership.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: This source is a review by Fatma Ben Slimane of Hélène Blais's book, *Mirages de la carte. L'invention de l'Algérie coloniale XIXe-XXe siècle*. The review outlines the book's central argument: that the territory of Algeria was continuously elaborated, rethought, redesigned, enlarged, and reinvented through colonial incursion. The book challenges both colonialist perceptions of Algeria as a purely colonial creation and nationalist views of a long-established Algerian nation within an identifiable territory. It explores the knowledge mobilized in understanding and appropriating Algerian terrain, the memories used by colonizers (scholars, military, engineers) in naming the space, the mapping process, and the role of local populations in this construction. The review highlights the book's focus on the discursive production in the geographic invention of the colony, the uncertainties and debates in the initial decades of French conquest regarding the colony's status, occupation, and even its name. It further discusses the role of cartography as a tool of colonial control and appropriation, driven by the metropole's demands. The maps, constantly redrawn, reflected the ongoing conquest and political context, and the challenge of rendering the alien social and geographic space intelligible. The review also notes the resistance the Algerian terrain (topography, landscapes, tribes, ways of life) posed to being mapped.

The article also explores the role of the Young Turks after 1895, with Tripoli becoming a meeting point for Tunisian refugees and exiled Young Turks, united in their opposition to French aggression and the Ottoman Porte's inaction. llm_processed_output.source_summary: This document is a master's thesis about the legal concept of the extended continental shelf and its practical application in Spain. It discusses the historical development of maritime spaces, focusing on the continental shelf, from the 18th century to the 1982 UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). It examines the legal divisions of maritime spaces, the definition and limits of the continental shelf, and the role of the Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf (CLPC). A significant portion analyzes the delimitation of Spanish maritime spaces, including zones of dispute with neighboring states like France, Portugal, and Morocco. Critically, it addresses the conflict concerning the delimitation between the Balearic Islands and Algeria, stating their coasts in the Mediterranean are potentially problematic in the delimitation of the Exclusive Economic Zone and the continental shelf. Although Algeria is one of the largest producers of hydrocarbons in Africa, the report argues these resources are located more than 2000 meters deep, which makes it commercially non-viable and very difficult to extract. The document also references the Spanish position that Algeria does not recognize the right of the islands, particularly the Balearic Islands, to generate an Exclusive Economic Zone, even though the zone of protection of both territories doesn't currently superimpose. The document also analyzes Spain's submissions to the CLPC, including the joint FISU presentation, the presentation in the Galicia area (in coordination with Portugal), and the presentation west of the Canary Islands. It discusses the challenges and complexities involved in each case, specifically the dispute with Portugal over the Savage Islands and the absence of a valid interlocutor for delimitation with the Western Sahara region.
extracted_key_facts: The document is a master's thesis on the legal concept of the extended continental shelf and its application in Spain (2017/2018).

The First UN Conference on the Law of the Sea in 1958 resulted in four conventions, including one on the Continental Shelf.
The Convention on the Continental Shelf (1958) defined the continental shelf based on depth (200 meters) and exploitability.
The Third UN Conference on the Law of the Sea (1982) culminated in UNCLOS, establishing the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and a more complex definition of the continental shelf.
UNCLOS defines the continental shelf as extending to the edge of the continental margin or 200 nautical miles.
The Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf (CLPC) reviews submissions from states seeking to extend their continental shelf beyond 200 nautical miles.
Spain is a party to UNCLOS and has its own regulations for maritime spaces.
Spain has signed bilateral agreements with France (1974) and Italy (1974) regarding maritime boundaries.
Spain is currently engaged in maritime boundary disputes with France, Portugal, Morocco, and the United Kingdom (Gibraltar).
The Balearic Islands and Algeria have potentially problematic coastlines in the Mediterranean for delimitation of the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and the continental shelf.
Algeria does not recognize the right of the Balearic Islands to generate an Exclusive Economic Zone.

Spain has submitted three presentations to the CLPC: a joint submission with France, Ireland, and the UK (FISU), a submission for the Galicia area (coordinated with Portugal), and a submission for the area west of the Canary Islands.
The FISU presentation has been approved by the CLPC, but the area still needs to be divided among the four countries (2009).
The submission for the Galicia area is coordinated with Portugal and involves an Area of Common Interest.

The submission for the area west of the Canary Islands is complicated by the dispute with Portugal over the Savage Islands and the lack of a valid interlocutor for delimitation with the Western Sahara region.
